titleStmt.title: Cambridge, St John's College, MS B.15

availability.p: Zooming image © University Library, All rights reserved.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, St John's College, MS B.15

supportDesc.support: Part 1 consists of paper quires with parchment outer and inner bifolia. Part 2 consists of paper leaves. Part 3 consists of parchment leaves.

foliation.p: Part 1 was foliated continuously in brown ink in the Early Modern Period, perhaps the 16th century. Part 2 was foliated continously in brown ink in the 15th century. Part 3 was foliated partially in pencil in the 20th century.
foliation.note: The leaf that is here identified as f. 44 does not feature the number '44' but this number almost certainly was once written on its original upper right-hand corner. However, this corner was torn off and later repaired with blank paper. Since this leaf was originally and intended to be foliated, the number '44' is here not placed between square brackets.

Part numbers were added to the manuscript's foliation in order to differentiate repeating folio numbers between the three parts (e.g. f. 1:1; f. 2:1; and f. 3:1); and the numbers [i]-[vi], [a]-[b], and [1:56]-[1:57] were assigned to unfoliated leaves for the purposes of this electronic record when the manuscript was examined in 2023 for the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project.

collation.p: This collation deviates from James (1913) and Claire Jones (2000). These differences are further explained in the collations for the separate parts.
collation.formula: 112-2 (1st and 2nd leaves missing) 210 312 412-1 (7th leaf cancelled) 510 6four | 712-2 (1st-2nd leaves missing) 818-4+1 or 20-5 (1st, 2nd, and 16th leaves missing, and 13th leaf cancelled) 912+2 (?2 added leaves after 12th leaf) 108 118-4 (or 8-5+1 (5th-8th leaves missing; 1st leaf may be from another quire) | 126 13-1412 1510 1612

signatures.p: Modern quire numbers (Arabic numerals) have been added in pencil to the lower right-hand corners of the first rectos of each quire

note.p: The manuscript features a table of contents added by the same 17th-century hand that recorded the donation of this manuscript to St John's College on the inside of the front cover.
A note on hours of daylight in September added in a 16th-century hand to f. [i] recto: September xij nocte vel xiij mane.

A description of the Four Elements in Middle English has been added by a 15th-century hand to f. [i] verso: ffyre hote and drye / herthe colde and drye / water cold and muste / Eyre hote and muste / ffyre acordyth wyth erthe in dryed hete (eVK2 v0072470000).
A medical recipe in Middle English has been added by a 15th-century hand to f. [i] verso: Scabyose stampid rie flore anaye \and/ hony / Scabiose qwyhsyluer gres.

A tract on the Four Elements and Humours in Latin has been added by a 15th-century hand to f. [ii] verso, beginning: [E]lementum dicitur vnius cuius rei inicium de quo sumitur incrementum in quo soluitur sicut sunt in anno .4. anni partes. sic sunt .4. elementa et .4. humores in homine. Que sunt in .4. qualitates sibi inuicem conueniencia vel discrepancia in modis istius figurae; and ending: Cum igitur dicta ista figura autumptnis est tempus malancolicum [sic] sic nulla parte anni malecolicis amittatur causa ex qua peruenit huius modi passio et sic effectus .i. ille morbus.

binding.p: 17th- or 18th-century blind-tooled dark brown leather over pulpboard; spine over five raised band featuring two paper labels with the printed classmark references 'B' and '15'; blue-tained fore-, top-, and tail-edges.

According to a note in pencil on the inside of the rear cover the manuscript was [r]esewn, rebacked, repaired (leather mending and guarding leaves) by John P. Gray and Son Ltd November 1967 for £4.10s'.

history.acquisition: Donated to St John’s College in by John Gent (d. 1651) Gent, John, d. 1651, BA St John's College 1625-6, Rector of Birdbrook, Essex, 1632-51: according to a 17th-century donor inscription on the inside of the inner cover: Ex dono Magistri Gent. Ecclesiae Burbrooke in Essexia rectoris hujusque Collegij alumnij nuperi.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of St John's College, Cambridge (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1913); and the description of the hands by Claire Jones, 'Vernacular literacy in late-medieval England: The Example of East Anglian Medical Manuscripts' (unpublished dissertation, University of Glasgow, 2000), pp. 197-198..

availability.p: Visitors to St John's College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: St John's College: Old Library and Special Collections)

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, St John's College, MS B 15, ff. 1:1-1:55, [1:56]-[1:57]

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes and charms
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes and Latin and Middle English charms with headers in Latin or Middle English
msItem.incipit: 1:1r er drynke þe poudyr of a bak er sonp it with a nesche ey
msItem.explicit: 1:29r pocio pro wlnere: Stampe mader in red cole lues and leues of hemp and tenze be euen with and sethe þes thinges in quit wine or in water and ley on þe wonde and red cole lef

note.p: The collection contains a wide variety of recipes, including recipes informed by popular beliefs. For example, a recipe for healing sore eyes (ff. 1:6r-1:6v) uses powder made from a swallow's chick and the gall of a puppy. The recipe instructs one to first prick out the eyes of the swallow's chick with a needle and then return to the next after nine days to find the chick again with restored eyesight. This practice is based on the belief that swallows had a magical stone with which they could heal their young. The recipe reads as follows: Take þe a swalwis brid out þe nest and tak a nedle and prikykyt [sic] in þe eyne til it is blind sithe put aȝen þat brid into þe nest and aftir ix dayes þou schal fynde þat bride wel seande tak þat brid and puttit with al þe fetheris into a clene newe erthene potte and bren it al to pouder take þan þe galle of a sokande qwelpe þat hath sokyd xxx dayes and tak two partes of þe pouder of castor and mdle al þis to gidere and putyt in a sorre eye.

Other recipes of note include a recipe for an ointment (vnguentum diacatum nobilissimum propter omnem gutam etcaetera fit) that involves and may be named after its first named ingredient, the fat of a yonge blak cat (f. 1:8v); a method to make a person sleep and wake them up, entitled: vt homo semper dormiat (f. 1:8v); a method to determine whether a woman is pregnant, entitled: To knowen ȝif a wimman be with childe (f. 1:12r) and a medical recipe for a venereal disease, entitled: Si virga hominis per mulierem vreatur (f. 1:13r); to determine whether a person has leprosy, entitled: To weten ȝif a man be a lepere or not (f. 1:13v).

The collection also contains various charms:
An instruction for making a birthing girdle from cloth and parchment onto which is written a charm to help a pregnant woman deliver a child: To don a wiman be deliuered of a child (ff. 1:7v-1:8r) [crossed out].
Saint William's charm for gout and other ailments: Þis is þe charm of seynt William þat angel gabriel brout him fro oure lord to j armen cristene men for worm and vein and goute and rancle and sor first do singyn a messe in hnour sancti spiritus et tunc dic istud carmen (ff. 1:23r-1:23v).
A charm for healing wounds that involves a led plate with five crossed on it: A charm to holen a wonde with a plate of led (ff. 1:23v-1:24r).
A charm agains fevers: ffor þe feueris Oracio bona (ff. 1:27r-1:27v) [the charm invokes King Edmund the martyr].
A charm against fevers: Contra febres + [the charm invokes 'seven sisters’ ('septem sorores') fever demons who are named after seven types of fever] (ff. 1:27v-1:28r).
A charm for healing a wound or sore: A charm for a wonde and for a sorre (f. 1:28r).

The collection also contains recipes that are not strictly aimed at healing:
Methods to control animals, including one to to prevent birds from nesting in trees: To kacchen briddis fro here nisterlynge (ff. 1:6v-1:7r and another one to drive flies away: ffor to don a wey flies (f. 1:8r).
A method to determine whether a woman is pregnant of a child and whether the child is a boy or a girl: To knowen ȝif a wiman be with childe (f. 1:12r);
Cosmetic recipes, including recipes to whiten one's teeth: To maken qwite tethe (f. 1:13v); To maken qwit teth (f. 1:14v); and: To maken a manis tetz qwite (f. 1:24v).

msItem.title: Antidotarium Nicholas
msItem.rubric: 1:29r Here ben wreten al þe names of diuerse receytes for alle euelis but here faylin mani for þe defaute of þe samplarte
msItem.incipit: 1:29r Aura alexandria: þe electuarie aurea alexandria is good for al eueels in a manis hed þat comen of cold and of rewme and of hete
msItem.explicit: 1:31r et datur cum vino albo

msItem.title: Work on the medical properties of herbs, resis, trees, stones and fruits
msItem.rubric: 31r To knowen alle herbis and gummes and treis and stones and frutes of qwat vertu þey ben and in qwat gre þei stonden vp fisike and [? S. J. N.]
msItem.incipit: 1:31r Calida in primo gradu sunt. Absinthium borago
msItem.explicit: 1:34r oua sorbilia vinum dulce ficus vne oua volitilium

msItem.title: List of salts and resins and their prices
msItem.textLang: Latin but with an English translation of one resin
msItem.rubric: 1:34r Septem sales sunt isti [...] Gumma sunt ista
msItem.incipit: 1:34r Sal communis id est salt de pety p. habet j d
msItem.explicit: 1:34v Bitumen anglice ter p. habet j d / Asa fetida

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 1:34v Vnguentum geneste for al maner akyngis and for þe splen: Tak þe blosmes of brom camomille walwort plantayne smal mader louache of iche euen porcion
msItem.explicit: 1:47r ȝif a manis tharm go out for nedyng at ȝe priue: Put it in a geyn with frech gres in a linen clout oftin and fele tymes and ȝif he come so fer out þat þou mit not put it in agayn take a l dubbil silk thred and striket with sum oniment and kut it as ner þe ars as þou mith and ley þer on a playster of diaculon and þe trid day knit þer a newe knot and so vset al gate with þe thred and with þe playstir til it be hol and dredit not for it wil do wel

note.p: The collection contains a reference to an unidentified medical practioner on f. 1:37v: Pouder of lif þat frere John Bacheler mad and it ȝaf men drinkyn for þe feueres and fo enpostemes.

The manuscript contains a number of gynaecological recipes:
A Medicine Magistrat for wimmen (f. 1:44v).
A Medicine to þe art of a midwife (f. 1:46r).
A medicine ffor þe matrice (f. 46r).
A medical bath described as a Medicine in þe malade afor þe matrice (f. 1:46r).
The collection contains a few charms: An orison for al maner woondes (f. 1:40r); and A charm of blak wolle and oile for wondes (ff. 1:40r-1:40v) [this is the so-called Tres Boni Fratres charm].

The collection contains a few instructions for magical applications of the heart of a kite (ff. 1:39v-1:40r: þat no wyld best ne nedder schal harmen no man / Quo bere bere vp on him an herte of a kyte þer schal no neder ne no wild best don him non harm þe herte of a kyte wonden in a lionis skyn or in a woluis fugat demones. þe stalke or þe fedir of a kite bondyn be þe left fot of a wimman and licȝ in gisine schal deliueren hire soon of hire child and qwan þe child is boren do awey faste þe stalke for peril of oþer thinges falande.

msItem.title: Four medical recipes to make hair grow or remove hair
msItem.incipit: 1:47r Take pyche and virgyn vax and bethe hem togedir
msItem.explicit: 1:47r Take þe wyte þat ben amonge pyssemerys ij penny weythe of on slekkyed lym and ballys blod and take þe yus of henbane and temper þere with an than anoynte þere þow wel bawe þe her awey
msItem.note: The recipes have been added by a different 15th-century hand than the collection on ff. 1:34v-1:47r.

msItem.title: Colection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 1:47v [I]n glandulis in collo. accipe micas panis albi mel et albumen oui misce
msItem.explicit: 1:48r Item occide Catulum et da pacienti fel eius bibere et liberabitur secure

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 1:47v prychyng of thorn - ffor the axis: Recipe rue wormode ffetherfue stonmarche tryakle
msItem.explicit: 1:47v ij dragmes of triacle de bois halfe a dragme of of mace halfe a dragme of [...]
msItem.note: The recipes have been added to the lower margin of f. 1:39v by a later 15th-century hand. They are missing the final line(s) of the last recipe due to cropping of the page.

msItem.title: Ointment for the skin
msItem.incipit: 1:48v Take ij hansvll of feltryke and of red rotes and a hansvll of aly compana rotes and a hansvll of redde docke rotes and strape them and waysse hem than take may boutter and pvt hem all together well stampyd in a panne and boylle hem all to gether and syth drawe them thorow a strayner and thys oyntment vse for þe fel
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by a later 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Collection of recipes for making pigments, adhesives, and gilded letters
msItem.incipit: 1:49r Gummed water: how þou schalt make þi gummed water
msItem.explicit: 1:51r Here schal I reherse þe compendyously al that I bifore seyde diffusely ffyrst drawe þi werke with a plumbet and sitthen
msItem.note: The recipes apparently form a collection. The collection's final line appears to be an introduction to a new section but abpruptly ends mid-sentence.

msItem.title: Recipes for medical ointments
msItem.incipit: 1:51r [O]leum rutaceum is good to vse . anoyntyn for collyca passio medelyd with buttir and rue and sethe it in oyle with esy fyir . than dry þe leuys and do hem aȝen to the oyle . þan do þerto v.e. of grene rue and sethe it aȝen alytel - Recipe the knoppys of the popul whenne they g\r/ou opyn put hem in a vessel with oyle . and so let hem stone . ix dayis . thanne sethe hem into thridde part and coule it thour a cloth do awey the dreftis . and kepe the oyle in a glas . or in a pot
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: A tract on onomancy
msItem.rubric: 1:51v Here begynnyth a proue for to wete of ij men þat fyȝth wit qweche party xal haue þe betterwit ni lystes . or of ij pelores qwo xal haue þe better. or of man or woman þat falle seke qweche party xal lyue or dye
msItem.incipit: 1:51v Here begynnyth a proue for to wete of ij men þat fyȝth wit qweche party xal haue þe betterwit ni lystes . or of ij pelores qwo xal haue þe better. or of man or woman þat falle seke qweche party xal lyue or dye
msItem.explicit: 1:52r Here begynnyth the letterys þe: a.3 [...] saturnus 26
msItem.note: The tract explains how one can foretell which party shall win a fight, whether the man or the woman in a married couple shall live the longest, and whether a sick man or a woman shall live or die by prognostications based on the letters of their first names

msItem.title: Onomantic calculations for situations involving two persons
msItem.incipit: 1:52r De egris numerando per nouem
msItem.explicit: 1:52r 99: 99 et 99 minor vincit

msItem.title: Method for determining whether a pregnant woman shall live on die through onomancy
msItem.incipit: 1:52r Also þe rule seruith for women wyth childe qwether sche chal lyue or dye
msItem.explicit: 1:52v vita [followed by a table with numbers]

msItem.title: Lucky and unlucky days for bloodletting
msItem.rubric: 1:52v Taken owt of arro [? arre] paters prouousty ca. 9 on for euer
msItem.incipit: 1:52v mastrys of estronymy and fysseke that thys crafte fyrste ewe fownd tellyth þe fyrste perelws dayes and þe most dangerv[s] dayes in þe yere in þe wyche yf any man or woman be late blod of wovnde \or/ of [crossed out: wh] vain they shall deye within xxj dayes folowyng
msItem.explicit: 1:53r In dessembyr are 3 dayes þe 6 and 7 and 19 et alij dicunt the 15 and the 16 [? or 18]
msItem.note: Part of the text is missing due to cropping of the page.

msItem.title: The Short Charter of Christ
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with Latin heading
msItem.incipit: 1:53r Wetyth now alle that ben here / And after schal be leue and dere
msItem.explicit: 1:53r This was ȝowyn at Caluerye / The fyrte day of the gret mercy

msItem.title: The Sphere of Apuleius or Sphere of Pythagoras
msItem.incipit: 1:53v [S]pera apulei placonici de vita vel de morte vel de omnibus negociijs vel quis quid in quirere volueris
msItem.explicit: 1:53v Si alio modo vis scire de egris si viuant au non. computa dies a J kl Julij usque in diem iii quo egris inciderit suptus diebus partiri per tres si viuis superauerit cito sanus erit si duo triduis si nullus [...]uetur
msItem.note: Below the text is a drawing of the Sphere of Life and Death.

msItem.title: Prognostications based on the weather on feast days
msItem.incipit: 1:54r [S]i die dominica circumcisio domini ceciderit yemps erit bona et ventosa
msItem.explicit: 1:54r vix bonus erit egris diu languesset et vix euadet omne inceptum illo die et anno non perueniet ad bonum perfectum etcaetera

msItem.title: Alchemical tricks
msItem.incipit: 1:54r [N]ota quod si argentum vinum ponatur in velica bene per
msItem.explicit: 1:54v si vis eciam ut olla non bulliat pone argentum vinum intus et non bulliet
msItem.note: This collection contains tricks with mercury for making a vessel move through the house, bread jump, a bird cry, a finger burn like a candle, and prevent a heated pot from boiling.

msItem.title: Pilatory recipes
msItem.incipit: 1:54v [S] vis ut pili non crescant. accipe magnas formicas et amputa capita corum et distempora corpora corum cum aceto et unge vbis vis
msItem.explicit: 1:54v [S]i vis ut pili deponatur accipe cepum calidum menbro applicate etiam si membrum aliquod vugatur cum succo herbe que vocatur betis ut pili crescant

msItem.title: Mantic alphabet
msItem.incipit: 1:54v [S]i vis scire quid sompnum tuum significat. Accipe psalterium et tene inter manus tuas clausum nec [...] et dic pater noster et postea benedicta sit hora in qua dominus ihesus Christus natus est et fac signum crucis in ymagine de super in nomine patris et aperto psalterio Christi latria que tibi apperuerit in summitate prime pagine signati sompni reuelabis per litteras secundum alphabeti igitur
msItem.explicit: 1:54v z significat plenitudinem g[? raciam]
msItem.note: Not listed in Chardonnens (2013), 340-366.

msItem.title: Tract on the Perilous Days
msItem.incipit: 1:54v [I]ste sunt dies male tocius anni et maxime periculosi. si quis in eis infrmitatem acciperit vix curabitur et si quis in eis nascitur non diu viuet et si qui mulierem despondauerit statim diuidentur vel cum dolore viuent et multa alia pericula pacientur. Isti
msItem.note: Full transcription; the text ends abruptly.

msItem.title: Tract on the Perilous Days
msItem.incipit: 1:54v [I]ste sunt dies male tocius anni et maxime periculosi. si quis in eis infrmitatem acciperit vix curabitur et si quis in eis nascitur non diu viuet et si qui mulierem despondauerit statim diuidentur vel cum dolore viuent et multa alia pericula pacientur. Isti
msItem.note: Full transcription; the text ends abruptly.

msItem.title: The Lord's Prayer (imperfect)
msItem.incipit: 1:55r our father wyche arte in hewyn halloy [...]
msItem.note: Full transcription; this is a single line added to the upper margin by another 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: The Lord's Prayer
msItem.incipit: 1:55r Oure fadyr þat art in heuene haluyd be þi name þi kymdam com to þi wyl
msItem.explicit: 1:55r and lede vs nowt into temptacioun but delyuyr \vs/ fro euyl Amen

msItem.title: Ave Maria
msItem.incipit: 1:55r Heyl mary ful of grace god is with the among all women blyssyd mote þou be and blyssyd be þe frute of þi body Jhesus Amen
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Apostolic Creed
msItem.incipit: 1:55r I beleue in god fadyr almythy make of heuyn and erthe and in his on begote son owre lord Jhesu cryst
msItem.explicit: 1:55r I beleue in þe holygost and in all holy chyrche and in þe comonyng of holy men and in forȝefnesse of synnys and in agaeyn rysyng of flesch and ay lestyng Amen

msItem.title: Poem on Christ's love
msItem.incipit: 1:55r loue I desyre and loue me be gyle / loue sesyth stryue loue lesyt my lyue
msItem.explicit: 1:55v Preue ȝour ♡ in swyche degre / That in ȝow ⸬ stedefast ȝe be

msItem.title: Tract on adultery
msItem.incipit: What man þat leuyth in adulterye shal haue þese paynes or he dye in this erthe. Aþþir he shal be pour or he shal dye sodenly Or he shal lese one of his membrys thorow a sodene chaunce or thorow a wounde Or he shal be defamyd be þe whiche he shal be kepte in presoun etcaetera
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Unfinished diagram, probably intended for a Sphere of Pythagoras or Apuleian Sphere
msItem.note: The outlines of the sphere are only visible, featuring cross lines to create four fields inside the sphere where information would be entered with which a patient's fate could be determined.

msItem.title: Poem
msItem.incipit: 1:56v Munus fit iudex frause est mercator in orbe
msItem.explicit: 1:56v Prudentes ceci cognati digneris [sic] sunt

msItem.title: The Abuses of Age [poem]
msItem.incipit: 1:56v Ȝeft is domus man and gyle is chapman
msItem.explicit: 1:56v Symonye is aboueand awey is trwloue

msItem.title: Reckoning of the numbers of parish churches, villages, religious, feudal knights, and counties in England
msItem.incipit: 1:56v Sunt in anglia ecclesie parochiales lxv ml et xi. Item ville CC ml Item feodum militum xl ml xv de quibus religiosi xx viij ml et xv Item comitatus xxxviiij
msItem.note: Full transcription.

support.material: Paper quires with inner and outer parchment leaves, except for quire 4 where the second and second to last leaves are parchment, and quire 5 where the inner leaves are paper.
Paper, folded in folio (watermarks at the centre of the inner margins have not been identified)

collation.note: The collation in this record deviates from that of James (1913) where the first quire is defined as a quinternion with its first leaf missing, and that of Claire Jones (2000) where the first quire is defined as an intact quinternion. Although the first quire presently indeed consists of ten leaves, it is clearly missing leaves at the beginning. That at least one leaf is missing is suggested by the fact that the quire opens with a paper leaf but that the quire ends with a parchment leaf. That, in fact, two leaves are missing is evident from the location of the (parchment) inner leaves at ff. 1:4-1:5, and the leaf numbers in the lower margins of the versos which appear to begin with '3' [cropped] and run until '12'. All of this makes clear that the first quire is a sexternion with two missing leaves before f. 1:1.

signatures.p: Leaf signatures in Roman numerals written in the lower margins of the versos of pages throughout each quire (f. 1:17 is the exception, where the leaf signature '9' has been written on the recto side), but regularly cropped off.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink in the right-hand lower margins of the last versos of quires.

p.seg: Ruled in ink, frame only, with occasional line ruling. 34-36 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: ff. 1:1r-1:13v and 1:16v-1:47r have been copied by a single scribe in an Anglicana hand.
ff. 1:14r-1:16r have been copied by a single scribe in a cursive script with both Anglicana and and Secretary features.
ff. 1:47r-1:48r have been copied by a single scribe in an upright Anglicana hand.
ff. 1:49r-1:52v have been copied by a single scribe a cursive script with both Anglicana and and Secretary features.
Additions to ff. 1:52v-1:53r are by a single scribe in a Secretary hand.
ff. 1:53r has been copied by a single scribe in an Anglicana hand.
ff. 1:53v-1:54v have been copied by a single scribe in a Bastard Anglicana script.
ff. 1:55r-1:[57] verso have been copied by various scribes in a cursive scripts with with both Anglicana and and Secretary features.
ff. 1:1r-1:47r have been copied by a single scribe in a cursive script with both Anglicana and and Secretary features.

decoNote.p: Diagram in red ink of a lead plate with five crosses used for a charm to heal wounds on f. 1:23v.
Large (2-line) plain initials in red ink, sometimes with minor foliate motifs inside their letters; one letter features a human face.
A capital letter 'M' decorated with a human face in brown ink on f. 1:12v.
Decorative line-filler consisting of a dragon drawn in red ink on f. 1:9v.
Heading for recipes written in red ink.
Underlining of headings for recipes in red ink.
Regular capitals occasionally highlighted in red ink (e.g. ff. 1:34r-1:34v).

msItem.title: A Herbal known as Agnus Castus (imperfect)
msItem.incipit: 2:3r superfluete of þe blacke colore. Also yt heylyth þe bytyng of veynomous beystes
msItem.explicit: 2:6v The vertuwe of þis herbe ys þat he ys gud to opyn þe feppyng of þe steppyng mylte and of þe lyuer þis herbe ys whote and dry
msItem.note: The herbal begins mid-sentence in the description of the medicinal uses of an "Pulogium regale". The first complete entries are for Pulogium montanum, Quinquefolium, and Rvta domestica. It is a previously unidentified copy of a late 14th-century herbal known as "Agnus Castus" (after its opening words, which are missing here). The manuscript is not included in Brodin (1950), pp. 30-31, where 29 extant manuscript copies and 5 early printed copies are listed.

msItem.title: Prognostics for patients
msItem.incipit: 2:6v De coginicione vite et mortis Macer dicit quod si quando visitas egrum portaueris veruenam et queras ab eo quomodo est tibi omni dicat bene eudet si dicat male non euadet
msItem.explicit: 2:7r Experimentum Cetera quere in principio libri in sputa putagoris

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection contains recipes against intoxication (Contra Ebrietatem) contains recipes against lice and mice (Contra pulices ad fugandum pulices and Contra mures) on f. 2:7r.

msItem.title: Three Good Brothers [Tres boni fratres] Charm
msItem.incipit: 8v Tres fratres per vnam viam ambulauerunt et obuiauit eos dominus noster ihesus Christus et dixit eis
msItem.explicit: 2:8v Ter dicatur Pater noster Aue maria et hoc carmen ter dicatur

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection contains recipes against lice: a schepys lowys or ony other quikke beyst yn hys hedes (f. 2:9v) and ffor to destry lyse (f. 2:10r; and a recipe to catch birds: ffor to take fowlys (f. 2:10r-2:10v).

msItem.title: The Letter of Ipocras
msItem.rubric: 2:10v Ipocras thys boke send to þe emperowr of cecari whyte þou þat thys boke ys gud leche with alle þyngys yt doth teyche do also thys boke bedyth yt techyt þynges to leychys al herewyt
msItem.incipit: 2:10v Of eyche maner euyl what eyuer yt be sone here aftyr þou myȝt see man or woman þat hath natur how þou schalt take eny hede now þou may take gud hede how þou myȝt thy body ȝeue eueryche maner best and worst þat body hauyth yn hym self fowr hum[o]urs.
msItem.explicit: 2:11r Thus þou schalt knowe be þe vrens alle þe euyllys of mannys body. When þou hast þe euelys yknowe her þou mayst se m[e]dcynnys and charmys for many euellys

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection is imperfect due to missing leaves: ff. 2:13-2:14.

The collection includes a charm to remove a dead child from a woman's womb on ff. 2:11v-2:12r; a charm to staunch blood (imperfect at the beginning) on f. 15r; a charm against toothache on f. 2:15r; a charm against fevers, invoking Christ encountering St Peter sitting on a stone weeping, on f. 2:15r; a charm to be recited while bloodletting on f. 2:15v.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection contains a charm for falling evil in a child. The text instructs one to take blood of the patient's little finger and writing the names of the Three Magi in a drinking vessel, wash it with ale or milk, and then give it the child to drink.
This collection largely consists of medical recipes in Latin copied by the same hand, but includes a few Middle English recipes that appear to have been added by a different hand.

msItem.title: Uroscropic tract
msItem.incipit: 2:19v vryna pura et supra nebula natans quasi caligo proximi mortem singnificat [sic]
msItem.explicit: 2:19v vrina mulieris [crossed out: corporis] corpore tumentis et tussientis et solucionem pacientis si colorem viridis sui habuerit non sanabile singnat [sic]
msItem.note: This text also occurs in London, British Library, Sloane MS 146, ff. 98r-98v.

msItem.title: Uroscopic tract
msItem.incipit: 2:20r Primum est ut substancia illius diligencius attendatur pars superiori
msItem.explicit: 2:21r Si vrina filit [?] colerata et in monendo appareant quasi sate singat habundanciam sanguinis et indiget fleobotoma

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Copied by a single hand, imperfect due to a missing leaf between ff. 2:27 and 2:29.

The collection contains a few other types of instructions: (A) Culinary recipes, including recipes to preserves of fruit called char conse and charde wardonys on ff. 2:22v-2:23r. (B) charms, including the so-called Sage Leaf Charm on f. 2:24v; a charm to conjure a sick person to foretell their own fate (whether they shall live or die) on ff. 2:29v-2:30r; a charm against thieves on ff. 2:30v-2:31r a charm for healing a wound (ffor to scharme a wond on englyche) on f. 2:40v; an instruction for making an amulet for a pregnant woman on ff. 2:40v-2:41r; a charm for dysentery (blody flyx) on f. 2:42r; a charm for healing toothache, invoking Sts Apollonia, Nicasius and Cassian, on ff. 2:42v-2:43r; and charm for the falling sickness and fever (ffor the fallyng Euylle or for the feuerys).

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes (imperfect)
msItem.note: Copied by a single hand, imperfect at the beginning and in between due to a missing leaf between ff. 2:100 and 2:102.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Copied by a single hand, imperfect due to missing leaves between ff. 2:138 and 2:141.

supportDesc.support:
Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 2:3r-2:44v: Staff of Aesculapius ?
Folios 2:99-2:144: Circle or Ring
Folios 2:138-2:144: Letter 'P'

list.item: Quire 818-4+1 or 20-5 (ff. 2:11-2:30: 1st, 2nd, and 16th leaves missing, and 13th leaf cancelled)
Quire 118-4 (ff. 2:138-2:143: 5th-8th leaves missing; 1st leaf may be from another quire)

note.seg: The collation in this record deviates from James (1913) where quire 7 is defined as a quaternion (ff. 2:3-2:10) and quire 8 as a quire of 18 leaves with one leaf cancelled (ff. 11-30), and Claire Jones (2000) where quire 7 is defined as a quaternion (ff. 2:3-2:10) and quire 8 as a quire of 18 leaves with its 13th leaf cancelled (ff. 2:11-2:30): this catalogue record assumes that quire 7 is a sexternion with 2 missing leaves at its beginning (ff. 2:3-2:12), which explains why there are two paper stubs in front of the quire and the medieval foliation starts at '3'. The location of the thread tackets in the gutter between f. 2:6 and f. 2:7 would support either theory but the original medieval foliation sequence suggests that quire 7 runs until f. 2:12 instead of f. 2:10.

James (1913) and Claire Jones (2000) think that quire 8 runs from f. 2:11 until f. 2:30. This quire would originally have consisted of 18 leaves but one leaf, leaf 13, was cancelled, now represented by a stub between f. 2:24 and f. 2:25. However, this collation disregards breaks in the original medieval foliation that suggest that three more leaves are no longer present: two leaves between f. 2:12 and f. 2:15 (i.e. there are no leaves with the folio numbers '13' and '14') and one leaf between f. 2:27 and f. 2:29 (i.e. there is no leaf with the folio number '28'). These jumps in the foliation coincide with breaks in the texts and with breaks in a medieval sequence of capital letters, organised in alphabetical order, that was added to the outer margins to indicate the beginnings of different sections of the recipes. Consequently, the absent numbers '13', '14', and '28' in the foliation cannot be the result of errors on the part of the foliator and must represent missing leaves.

The observation that three leaves are missing from quire 8, in addition to the cancelled leaf, means that quire 8 would have had at least 21 leaves if it indeed started at f. 11. Placing the quire's start at the missing f. [13] also gives an uneven number: namely, a quire of 19 leaves. It is therefore possible that one leaf was cancelled from the first half of the quire (ff. [2:13]-2:21) or added to the second half of the quire (ff. 2:22-2:30). In other words, quire 8 is likely to have been a quire of 18 with an additional leaf in its second half or a quire of 20 from which one leaf was cancelled in it's first half.

Further foliation breaks suggest that there might be other anomalies in the collation: In quire 10 the foliation jumps from '100' to '101' and in quire 11 it jumps from '138' to '140' but in neither case has it been possible to conclusively determine whether these jumps coincide with breaks in the text.

p.seg: Ruled in drypoint, frame only. Single columns. 28-31 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Copied by several hands in cursive scripts with both anglicana and secretary features: Hands A and B (ff. 2:3r-2:107v) and Hand C (ff. 2:138r-2:143v).

decoNote.p: Headers for texts written in red ink.
Regular capitals in brown ink occasionally highlighted with red ink.

origin.origDate: Copied in the second half of the 15th century.

history.provenance: John Burd (fl. 16th century) Burd, John, fl. 16th century, owned the manuscript according to an inscription on f. 25r: John Burd Owe Thys boke witnes John Brenoke In the [...]. His name is also inscribed in the upper margins of ff. 2:23r and 2:24r
Henry Fishburn (? fl. 17th century) Fishburn, Henry, fl. ? 17th century, his name inscribed in the lower margin of f. 2:4r: Henery Fichurne.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, St John's College, MS B.15, ff. 3:1-3:52

msItem.title: Calendar
msItem.incipit: 3:1r Januarius habet dies. xxxi. Luna. xxxix.
msItem.explicit: 3:6v Nox habet horas. xviii. dies horas vj.
msItem.note: Written in red ink on f. 3:5r is: Dedicacio ecclesie Noricensis.anno domini .M.o cc.o ix .lc.
The feasts of Thomas Becket have been crossed out.
An early modern hand has added Latin and English words with letters of the Greek alphabet, featuring, on f. 3:5r, the year 1607.

msItem.title: Preface to the Antidotarium magnum
msItem.incipit: 3:37r Alle miȝti god þat made al þinge fader and sone holigost . alle he clyp at biginninge . and he it made for mannis loue moste. þat man schylde knawe wat were gode and euele . þe god to take þe euel to for sake. of wich þinggis ben writing in þis litil boke. bi witnesinge of philosophers and docturs and oþer men of discrecion wich men dispicten and acorden þat is to sayn. Galien. ypocras and auicenne. and sayeþ þat man hþ in his bodi. iiij. humours. þat maket him for to liuen
msItem.explicit: 3:7v þe first medicine þat is write in þis liil boke is cleped. Aurea alexandrina; for sondri passions þat comeþ of cold. Aftir him comeþ oþere al þis kalender makeþ schewynge

msItem.title: Table of contents of the Antidotarium magnum
msItem.incipit: 3:7v Aurea alexandrina .i.
msItem.explicit: 3:8v Sequitur laxatiuis

msItem.title: Antidotarium magnum
msItem.textLang: Middle English with East Anglian dialectal variatinos [see Carillo-Linares (2005), pp. 75-78, 89]recipes with Latin headings
msItem.incipit: 3:8r Aurea dicitur ab auro in multis passionibus probata. it is god for rewme. and for ake of efde
msItem.explicit: 3:39v Anoþer. Take .mirre. storac. gariofilate. þe betus of lorer. mugwort. broþerwort. castor. ana ℥.j and s. canel ℥.j. and s. and huse hit boþe fastinde and ful. sufficit de hiis
msItem.note: According to Carrillo Linares (2005), this is a partial translation of "Group B" of the Antidotarium Nicholas. However, Green (2019), pp. 4-5 fn 15, argues that "Group B" is the Antidotarium magnum on which the Antidotarium Nicolai is based

msItem.title: Preface to the Antidotarium Nicholai
msItem.incipit: 3:40r Hec sunt que subtili ingenio ac solerti studio summaque diligencia ordinauimus ad opus omnium in arte medicinali studere uolencium
msItem.explicit: 3:41r et cum dispensandi habeant copiam de inimicorum et amicorum plenitudine glorientur

msItem.title: Antidotarium Nicholai
msItem.incipit: 3:41r Aurea alexandrina ut supradictum est: Aurea; xviij pars est
msItem.explicit: 3:45v [...] quod sufficit

msItem.title: Lists of herbs grouped according to their properties and degrees
msItem.incipit: 3:45v Diuretica calida: Apium. petrofilium. feniculis. sparagus.
msItem.explicit: 3:48v vrtice piper nigrum

msItem.title: Latin-English glossary of herbs
msItem.rubric: 3:48v Hic incipit nomina herbarum in primis
msItem.incipit: 3:48v Ambrose .i. hinde lyle hoc est wylde sage.
msItem.explicit: 3:51r Zanara. bissoppis gresse
msItem.note: A similar if not near-identical version of this text survives in London, British Library, Harley MS 2378, ff. 113r-117r.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Added by different 15th-century hands; only the first recipe is in Middle English: for to brekyn abike.

msItem.title: Memorandum
msItem.note: Written upside down, but almost completely erased and crossed out.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only, with occasional line ruling. Single columns. 20 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: ff. 3:1r-3:51r have been copied by a single scribe in semi-textualis.
Additions to ff. 3:51r-3:52r have been made by several hands in cursive anglicana scripts.

decoNote.p: 1 large (7 lines) historiated puzzle initial 'A' in blue and red ink with penwork decroation in blue and red ink, featuring interlace and foliate motifs on f. 3:7r. Inside the letter is a figure painted in colours against a gold ground: Christ in a green and purple robe depicted as "Salvator Mundi", making the sign of the cross with his right hand while holding a orb in his left hand.

1 large (5 lines) historiated puzzle initial 'A' in blue and red ink on f. 3:5r. Inside the letter is a figure painted in colours against a gold ground: a physician in an orange rob and wearing a green cap (?) holding up a green-coloured urine flask with their left hand and pinting to the flask with their right hand.
Large (3-4 lines) puzzle initials in blue and red with penwork in red ink.
Large (2-3 lines) initials in blue or red ink with penwork decoration in the opposite colour.
Small (1 line) plain initials in blue or red ink, sometimes with penwork decoration in the opposite colour.
Headings for recipes written in red ink.
Regular capitals in brown ink occasionally highlighted with red ink.

origin.origDate: Copied in the second half of the 14th century.

provenance.p: Tomsun Tomsun, their late 15th- or early 16th-century ownership inscriptions in the upper margin of f. 3:7r and f. 3:51r: Liber M[?agistri] Tomsun.
R.L. R.L., accessed or owned the manuscript as is suggested by a cropped inscription on f. 3:51v: Anno domini 1590 R.L. [?].
Robert Marrow (fl. 17th century) Marrow, Robert, fl. 17th century: owned or accessed the manuscript. Their name inscribed in the upper margin of f. 3:11r.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
